title: 109_s56
content:
The "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area and defines key terms like Commission and Secretary. Establishment of Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado to conserve, restore, and protect natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources along the Rio Grande River. Boundaries extend from Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge to New Mexico State border, with a 1/4 mile buffer on each side. Secretary to prepare map and legal description, available for public inspection. Commission to be established. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management, Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge, Colorado Division of Wildlife, Colorado Division of Water Resources, Rio Grande Water Conservation District, and members from the general public in the local region. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, with expertise in preservation, restoration, and use of the Natural Area. Members serve a 5-year term, may be reappointed, and serve without compensation. The Commission elects a chairperson, meets quarterly, holds public meetings, and receives technical assistance from federal agencies. Federal agencies must provide information and technical services requested by the Rio Grande Natural Area Commission to assist in carrying out its duties. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission has the power to request information and technical services from federal agencies to fulfill its duties. The Commission may conduct hearings, enter into cooperative agreements for managing non-Federal land, prohibit acquisition of real property, and implement a management plan. The Commission will assist the Secretary in implementing the management plan to preserve and interpret the natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources of the Natural Area. This includes activities such as assisting the State of Colorado in preserving State land and wildlife, increasing public awareness of the resources in the area, encouraging land use policies consistent with the management plan, and assisting private landowners. The Commission will assist private landowners in the Natural Area with implementing the management plan. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary and the Commission, along with relevant agencies and private landowners, must prepare management plans for the Natural Area within 4 years of this Act. The Secretary will handle Federal land management, while the Commission will manage non-Federal land and submit their plan for approval by the Secretary. The Commission must notify the Secretary of reasons for disapproval and allow for revisions to the management plan. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land. The management plans must consider existing Federal, State, and local plans to present a unified preservation, restoration, and conservation plan for the Natural Area. Additionally, the plans for Federal land in the Natural Area must comply with specific requirements outlined in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The Secretary shall publish notice of the management plans in the Federal Register, which should include recommendations for resource management policies to protect and preserve the Natural Area's resources while promoting solitude, quiet use, and pristine natural values. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION OF NATURAL AREA. The Secretary administers the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws and the management plan, focusing on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources. This includes allowing for education, scientific study, and limited public recreation while protecting wildlife habitat and prohibiting water storage facilities and reducing motorized vehicle use. The management plan for the Natural Area includes restrictions on motorized vehicles and roads, encouraging negotiations for beneficial streamflow changes, applying to private land with owner consent, withdrawing Federal land from various uses, and allowing for land acquisition. The Secretary may acquire land in the Natural Area from willing sellers through purchase, exchange, or donation, to be administered according to the management plan and this Act. Section 5(d)(1) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act does not apply to the Natural Area. SEC. 8. EFFECT.

This Act does not conflict with the Rio Grande Compact, regulate private land in the Natural Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create Federal water rights, impose stricter water quality standards, or prevent Colorado from acquiring instream flow rights. 

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Funding is authorized to carry out this Act.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION.
